div.p: Expatriate Southerner here. Probably the last generation that cared much for the Lost Cause was the conveniently-named Lost Generation. The Depression, FDR, WW2 and the Cold War unified America the way that little has before or since and erased a large number of regional and ethnic identifications from Norwegians in the upper plains to Italians in NYC. This included Southerners. My Greatest Generation grandfather was American before he was Southern.

Later in the 1970's and 80's after the Civil Rights movement and social disruptions of the 60's had settled, American pop culture underwent a phase of romantic infatuation with the South. Every year saw the release of a half-dozen movies set in the South, Southern Rock was climbing the charts with the Allman Brothers and Lynard Skynard and the Dukes of Hazzard were ramp-jumping all over prime time in a car named after Robert E. Lee with a Confederate battle flag painted on the roof. That wasn't much of a shock. The battle flag was everywhere in the south and out of it, where it was taken as a symbol of rock-and-roll rebellion. Guns and Roses performed in front of a giant battle flag. So did Tom Petty. So did Pantera. When the Dukes of Hazzard movie came out in 2005, guess what was painted on the roof of the General Lee?
So, the battle flag has gone from nostalgiac to forgotten to cool to evil all in a century. You can forgive a Southerner's head for spinning. We're a little slow.

From my perspective, it's just a flag, and a flag is a symbol, and a symbol is always a proxy for something else. And in this case, I don't think the associations are that complex. People attack the flag to attack the South, because the South is a strong Republican voting block, and it keeps the more enlightened coastal enclaves from complete political dominance of the country. I don't think it's any more complex than that, and if the South went back to being a quaint dem-voting backwater, animosity to the battle flag would likewise disappear.
So why do Southerners defend the flag? They know you don't really hate a piece of cloth; you hate them.
As a further note to your sister: everything she thinks is good today will be bad tomorrow. Every generation has to learn the hard way, mine included.
